Fig 7 Mechanism and chemoselectivity of nitrile hydrosilylation catalyzed by [E-Rh] (E=Al, Ga, In) heterobimetallic catalysts: A theoretical perspective Yuanyuan Sun Writing – original draft Formal analysis Data curation Yanli Zeng Funding acquisition Formal analysis Xiaoyan Li Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Conceptualization ⁎ College of Chemistry and Material Science, Hebei Key Laboratory of Inorganic and Nano-Materials, National Demonstratin Center for Experimental Chemistry, Hebei Normal University, Shijiazhuang, 050024, PR China College of Chemistry and Material Science Hebei Key Laboratory of Inorganic and Nano-Materials National Demonstratin Center for Experimental Chemistry Hebei Normal University Shijiazhuang 050024 PR China College of Chemistry and Material Science, Hebei Key Laboratory of Inorganic and Nano-Materials, National Demonstratin Center for Experimental Chemistry, Hebei Normal University, Shijiazhuang, 050024, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Transition metals catalyzed hydrosilylation reaction is of significant values in organic synthesis. Herein the detailed mechanisms of the phenylacetonitrile hydrosilylation catalyzed by bimetallic [E-Rh] (E=Al, Ga, In) catalysts, as well as the RhCl(PPh3)3 monometallic catalyst, were investigated by DFT calculations. The electronic structure analysis indicates that the different atomic contributions of the Rh atom in E-Rh bond result in the polarity variations of the metal-metal bonds and different catalytic activities. The whole catalyzed cycle involves five processes: the formation of rhodium hydride complex, activation of H2SiMe2, insertion of phenylacetonitrile, reductive elimination, and isomerization. The reaction activities of [E-Rh] (E=Al, Ga, In) decrease successively, which is in agreement with the atomic contributions of Rh in three catalysts. DI analysis provides the evidence that the catalytic activity is controlled by the distortion energy of rate-determining state. QTAIM analysis shows the transformation of the Cl atom between two metal atoms, providing a clear description for structural changes in catalytic cycle. Graphical abstract The detailed mechanisms and chemoselectivity of the nitrile hydrosilylation catalyzed by the heterobimetallic [E-Rh] (E=Al, Ga, In) catalysts were investigated by DFT study. The activity sequence of E=Ga>>Al and In has been explained. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydrosilylation Heterobimetallic complex Reaction mechanism Catalytic activity Cl bridge Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrosilylation represents a significant method for the reduction of alkynes, alkenes, and nitriles, which have a wide range of applications in materials chemistry and coordination chemistry [1–4]. The hydrosilylation of nitriles is a highly potential reaction in organic synthesis and drug synthesis, as these reactions result in the formation of important imine intermediates. Unfortunately, nitriles are usually less reactive than other carbonyl complexes [5], which present a challenge in the use of this reaction. Moreover, the effective control of the chemoselectivity in the hydrosilylation reaction of nitriles to produce the N-silylimine remains difficult. As early as 1998, the successful identification of N-(trimethylsilyl)imines was achieved as a result of nitriles reacted with lithium aluminum triethoxy hydride or lithium aluminum n‑butyl diisopropyl hydride [6]. However, due to the harsh reaction conditions and the limitation of substrate scope, etc., the use of various transition metal catalysts has increased to explore the mild method for the chemoselective formation of imines experimentally. In particular, the monometallic catalysts based on Co [7,8], Zn [9,10], Ru [11–15], Rh [16,17], Ir [18,19], and Fe [20], etc. have demonstrated good performances in the selective hydrosilylation of nitriles and alkynes. Additionally, new bimetallic catalysts [21–23] containing metal-metal bonds with high efficiency and selectivity have been synthesized and used in organic reactions, which exhibit unique properties due to the synergistic interaction between the two transition metals. The rapid development of organic catalysis has facilitated the development of highly efficient bimetallic catalysts in the hydrosilylation reaction [24,25]. In 2018, thiolate-bridged dirhodium complexes were employed in the hydrosilylation of terminal alkynes, with a highly regio- and stereoselective product, β-(Z) vinylsilanes being produced [26]. Concurrently, it was demonstrated that the dirhodium complexes exhibited good functional group compatibility and mild reaction conditions as well as a wide range of reaction substrates. Afterward, Zhang et al. [27–29] reported the use of dirhodium(II) complexes in the hydrosilylation of alkynes, conjugated dienes and alkenes with various tertiary silanes, resulting in the production of vinylsilanes in excellent selectivities and yields. However, the use of bimetallic complexes for the hydrosilylation of nitriles is relatively rare. Recently, Iwasawa et al. [5] reported the hydrosilylation of nitriles catalyzed by heterobimetallic [E-Rh] (E=Al, Ga, In, denoted as 2-Al, 2-Ga, and 2-In, respectively) complexes (Scheme 1 ). In the [E-Rh] complexes, the Al, Ga, and In metal locate in the center of the pincer ligand, which is stabilized by steric hindrance. The three-coordinated pincer ligand causes a partially exposed Al, Ga, and In centers, which making the Rh atom act as the main reaction site. The interesting result is although the E metals are not the activity site, they have significant influences on the activities of the Rh atom. Among these three heterobimetallic complexes, only 2-Ga exhibited high reactivities and chemoselectivity for the hydrosilylation of the nitrile, whereas no reaction was observed in 2-In and low yield in 2-Al. The current study was focused on the mechanisms of phenylacetonitrile hydrosilylation catalyzed by 2-Al, 2-Ga, and 2-In via density functional theory (DFT) calculations to figure out the reasons for the various catalytic activities of bimetallic catalysts formed with different group 13 metal atoms. The main purposes of this study are (1) to elucidate the detailed reaction mechanism catalyzed by 2-Al, 2-Ga, and 2-In in phenylacetonitrile hydrosilylation; (2) to provide explanations for the factors that affect the catalytic activities of bimetallic catalysts formed with various group 13 metal atoms as well as to identify the reasons for the superior catalytic activity of the 2-Ga in comparison to 2-Al and 2-In; and (3) to understand the chemoselectivity of the title reaction. 2 Computational details All geometries of the reactants, intermediates, transition states (TSs), and products were fully optimized at the PBE-D3 [30–32]/def2-SVP [33,34] level using the Gaussian 16 package [35]. Vibrational analysis was carried out at the same level to determine the stationary points on the potential energy surface (PES). No imaginary frequency was detected in the stationary points, whereas only one imaginary frequency was observed in the TS. Intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) [36,37] calculations were performed to verify the validity of each reaction pathway. To achieve high accuracy in energy calculation, the single-point energy was calculated at the PBE-D3/def2-TZVP [38] level, using the conductor polarized continuum model (CPCM) [39] with tetrahydrofuran as solvent to take into account the solvent effect. The solution translational entropy correction was obtained using Fang's THERMO program [40]. All calculations were performed at standard conditions, 298.15 K and 1atm. The review of Schoenebeck suggested that hybrid mGGAs perform better than hybrid GGAs for energy barriers [41,42]. To ensure the accuracy of the results, different DFT methods, including GGA, hybrid GGA, and hybrid mGGA (listed in Table S1), were used for geometry optimization and the single point energy calculations. It was found that the PBE0-D3 gives similar results compared to the PBE-D3 functional, and consistent with the experimental results, while those of M06-l-D3, B3LYP-D3 and M06–2X-D3 are poor. The PBE density functional is regarded as one of the “fastest” and most cost-effective calculation methods to determine the exact geometry and thermochemistry [43,44], and is widely used for metal systems and their reactivity [45,46]. Therefore, the results gotten from the PBE-D3 function are reasonable and this method is employed in this work. The reaction rate constants were calculated with the Concvar program [47] based on the transition state theory [48]. The Multiwfn 3.8 program [49] and VMD program [50] were used to perform the molecular dipole moment diagrams. The electron location function (ELF) analysis [51–53] was performed using Topmod programs, and the UCSF Chimera program [54] was used to plot the ELF graphs. Based on the Quantum Theory of “Atoms in Molecules” (QTAIM) [55,56], the topological parameters at the bond critical points (BCPs) were obtained by using the AIMALL program [57]. All the geometries of the stationary points were displayed using the CYLview software [58]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Formation of rhodium hydride catalyst The experimental results reported by Iwasawa et al. [5] (Scheme 1) and the preliminary study of the reaction mechanism suggest that the heterobimetallic [E-Rh] complexes and silane may firstly form an intermediate of the rhodium hydride complex, which is the real catalyst in the subsequent reaction (Scheme 2 ). The title reaction is shown in Scheme 1. The calculated potential energy surface (PES) profile to obtain the rhodium hydride catalyst from 2-Al, 2-Ga, and 2-In is shown in Fig. 1 . The optimized geometries of the stationary points of the PES of 2-Al are shown in Fig. S1 with the main parameters labeled. Those of 2-Ga and 2-In are shown in Fig. S2. The optimized xyz coordinates of all of the stationary points on the potential energy profile are shown in the SI.xyz. 3.1.1 Formation mechanism of rhodium hydride catalyst from 2-Al, 2-Ga and 2-In As shown in Figs. 1 and S1, the formation of rhodium hydride catalyst involves two steps: activation of H2SiMe2 and Cl-Si coupling. Take 2-Al as an example, initially, H2SiMe2 (denoted as 1) reacts with 2-Al to form Al-COM1. During this step, the bond length of the Rh-Al bond in 2-Al increases slightly, the Si-H bond length in H2SiMe2 increases from 1.509 Å to 1.547 Å, and the Rh-H bond length is 2.011 Å. As the reaction proceeding, the Rh-H gradually shorten to 1.881 Å and Rh-Si bonds to 3.019 Å, Al-TS1 arrives. After Al-TS1, Al-INT1 is formed with the Rh-H bond length of 1.580 Å and the Rh-Si bond length of 2.403 Å. The energy barrier of this step is 16.7 kcal/mol. Subsequently, the bond length of the Si-Cl1 bond continues to decrease as the Rh-Si and Rh-Cl1 bonds gradually increase, and Al-INT2 is formed through the Si-Cl1 coupling via Al-TS2. In Al-TS2, the bond lengths of Rh-Si, Rh-Cl1, and Si-Cl1 are 2.946 Å, 2.562 Å, and 2.281 Å, respectively, and the energy barrier of this step is 16.6 kcal/mol. The rhodium hydride catalyst Al-RhH is generated eventually. The reaction processes of H2SiMe2 react with 2-Ga and 2-In are similar to that with 2-Al. Seen from Figs. 1 and S2, when 2-Ga is employed in the reaction, the energy barrier required for the activation of H2SiMe2 and the Cl-Si coupling step is 23.4 kcal/mol and 11.9 kcal/mol, respectively, while when 2-In is used, the energy barrier for the activation of H2SiMe2 and the Cl-Si coupling is 28.9 kcal/mol and 8.8 kcal/mol, respectively. A comparison of the energy barrier for the rate-determining step (the activation of H2SiMe2) in the formation of the rhodium hydrogen complexes process reveals that the energy barrier of reacts H2SiMe2 with 2-Ga is 23.4 kcal/mol, which can occur under experimental conditions. While for the reaction with 2-In, the energy barrier is high to 28.9 kcal/mol, its half-life from this barrier is approximately 68 h, much longer than the experimental time (7 h), which indicating that the reaction is difficult to perform under this experimental condition. These are consistent with the experimental results that the reaction of H2SiMe2 with phenylacetonitrile activated by 2-Ga gave rise to the products A and B, no products were observed when the title reaction was activated by 2-In [5]. The result of H2SiMe2 reacts with 2-Al is surprising. The energy barrier is low, only 16.7 kcal/mol, while no products were observed when the title reaction was activated by 2-Al, the same as that of 2-In [5]. In order to identify the reason for the unusual behavior that no products were observed when the title reaction was activated by 2-Al, the time-dependent concentration variations of the reactants and products were calculated and given in Fig. 2 . This method is used to numerically calculate the change in concentration over time according to reaction rate constants estimated from free energy barriers. Usually, the concentration of the reactant is set to a certain value, and after simulating the above reaction long enough at the reaction temperature, checking the concentrations of the two products, then the main product and the ratio of the products will be directly given. For the reaction of 2-Al activated of H2SiMe2 process (Fig. 2(a)), as the reaction proceeding, the concentration of Al-INT1 rises significantly while the reactant H2SiMe2 decreases, but the increase of Al-RhH is slow, less than 20% of Al-RhH is formed and Al-INT1 is the main product. We also investigate the following reaction pathway catalyzed by Al-RhH, the whole Gibbs energy profile is presented in Fig. S3. It shows that the following rate-determining step is the hydrosilylation process, with the energy barrier of 20.9 kcal/mol. Under the experimental conditions (343 K, 7 h), this energy barrier is too low, which indicating that the reaction would proceeds too easy to control. Moreover, the high reaction temperature would reduce the stability of Al-RhH catalyst, as proposed by Iwasawa et al. [5], thereby making the subsequent hydrogenation reactions is difficult. Our analysis is consistent with the low yield in 2-Al catalyzed system. For the reaction activated by 2-Ga (Fig. 2(b)), the ratio of the formation of Ga-RhH to Ga-INT1 is about 4:1, that is, 2-Ga has the ability to create more Ga-RhH complex, which act as a catalyst for the subsequent reaction. In contrast, the reaction activated by 2-In (Fig. 2(c)) continued for approximately 23.6 h without any observable results. 3.1.2 Electronic structure of Ga-RhH To obtain a deeper understanding of the electronic structures and spectroscopic characteristics of the E-RhH (E=Al, Ga, In) catalyst, the NPA (natural population analysis) charges, the wiberg bond index, and the IR spectrum of the Rh-H stretching vibration of these three catalysts were calculated on each E-Rh (E=Al, Ga, In) bond. The Wiberg bond indices for Al-RhH, Ga-RhH, and In-RhH are 0.396, 0.494, and 0.586, respectively, which indicating that the E-Rh bonds are single bonds. The NPA charge of the Rh atom is −1.002 e, −0.991 e, and −1.072 e for each of these three catalysts, demonstrating a significant electron withdrawing ability of Ga. Fig. S4 gives the calculated IR spectra, which show that there is a strong Rh-H stretching vibration at about 2000 cm-1 for each E-RhH (E=Al, Ga, In) catalyst, providing a theoretical basis for the experimental detection of the hydride intermediates. 3.1.3 Influenced factors for different reaction activities in 2-Al, 2-Ga and 2-In As discussed above, the Rh atom is the only active site in the [E-Rh] (E=Al, Ga, In)] bimetallic catalysts, while the Al, Ga, and In metals do not participated to the reaction directly. Nevertheless, these three different metals result in different reaction activities at the Rh atom. In these three heterobimetallic complexes, only 2-Ga exhibited high reactivities and chemoselectivity for the hydrosilylation of the nitrile, whereas no reaction was observed in 2-Al and 2-In. In order to deep understand this phenomenon, the geometries and electronic analysis on [E-Rh], as well as the distortion/interaction analysis are performed. 3.1.4 Electronic structure of 2-Al, 2-Ga, and 2-In To illustrate the electronic structures of 2-Al, 2-Ga, 2-In, the electron location function (ELF) analysis are performed on each E-Rh (E=Al, Ga, In) bond. The ELF maps of Fig. 3 (a) indicate the presence of one disynaptic valence basin V(Rh, Al), V(Rh, Ga), and V(Rh, In) in 2-Al, 2-Ga, 2-In, respectively, with the population of each V(Rh, E) basin of 1.32, 1.69, and 1.66. Therefore, the E-Rh (E=Al, Ga, In) bonds can be characterized as covalent singlet bonds. However, there is a significant difference in the calculated atomic contributions of the Rh atom and the Al, Ga, and In atoms in the V(Rh, E) basin. The Rh atom accounts for the major contribution in the Rh-Al bond, with an atomic contribution of 74.6%, while Al is 25.4%. In the case of Rh-Ga bond, the atomic contribution of Rh decreases to 39.9%, that of Ga increases to 60.1%. In the 2-In, the atomic contribution of In atom is high to 93.3%, with the Rh has the lowest contribution of 6.7%. The calculated polarity of the Rh-Al, Rh-Ga, and Rh-In bonds is dependent on the atomic contribution of the V(Rh, E) (E=Al, Ga, In) basin, as illustrated in Fig. 3(b). The red arrows point to the direction of the dipole moment. It is visible that in 2-Al, the dipole moment points from Al to Rh. As the contribution of the Rh atom decreases, the direction of the dipole moment changes from the Rh atom to the Ga or In atom. The directional changes of the dipole moment lead to the different reaction activities of 2-Al, 2-Ga, and 2-In. 3.1.4 Distortion/interaction analysis Distortion/interaction analysis is proposed to be an efficient tool for elucidating the reasons for the observed differences in reaction activities. Within this model, the activation energy (ΔE) is decomposed into distortion energy (ΔE dist) and interaction energy (ΔE int). The distortion energy and the interaction energy of Al-TS1, Ga-TS1, and In-TS1 are shown in Fig. 4 . It clearly shows that the interaction energies are similar, the distortion energy difference between ΔE dist,Ga and ΔE dist,Al is 4.0 kcal/mol, while a difference of 10.2 kcal/mol is observed between ΔE dist,In and ΔE dist,Al. The difference in distortion energy between ΔE dist,In and ΔE dist,Al is more than twice that observed between ΔE dist,Ga and ΔE dist,Al. Therefore, the reaction activity is controlled by the distortion energy. In summary, the formation of rhodium hydride catalyst involves two processes. Only 2-Ga shows a good catalytic activity, whereas 2-Al and 2-In are inactive. The kinetic investigation yielded identical conclusions to the PES analysis, explaining the reason that the 2-Al with the lowest calculated energy barrier, but no products were detected in the whole experiments, which consistent well with Iwasawa's experimental observations [5]. Distortion/interaction analysis indicates that the reaction activity is controlled by the distortion energy. 3.2 Reaction mechanism for the hydrosilylation of phenylacetonitrile catalyzed by Ga-RhH Based on the results of Iwasawa et al. [5], the rhodium hydride complexes are the real catalyst in the subsequent reaction. The whole reaction mechanism involves five processes: the formation of rhodium hydride complex; activation of H2SiMe2; insertion of phenylacetonitrile; reductive elimination; and isomerization. The mechanism for the hydrosilylation of phenylacetonitrile catalyzed by Ga-RhH is displayed in Scheme 2. 3.2.1 Activation of H2SiMe2 The PES of the hydrosilylation of phenylacetonitrile (denoted as 3) to produce A catalyzed by Ga-RhH is shown in Fig. 5 , the optimized geometries of the stationary points are presented in Fig. S5 with the main parameters labeled. As shown in Scheme 2 and Fig. 5, the remaining process occurs via four processes: activation of H2SiMe2, insertion of phenylacetonitrile, reductive elimination, and isomerization. After the formation of Ga-RhH, H2SiMe2 first comes to Ga-RhH to form COM2. Then, the H and Si atoms of H2SiMe2 gradually approach the Rh atom to generate INT3 through TS3. In TS3, the bond lengths of Rh-H and Rh-Si are 1.658 Å and 2.419 Å, respectively. Additionally, the Si-H bond length also increases from 1.604 Å in COM2 to 1.806 Å in TS3. As the reaction proceeds, the bond lengths of Rh-H and Rh-Si are decreased. In INT3, the bond length of Rh-H is 1.628 Å and that of the Rh-Si is 2.405 Å, suggesting that H2SiMe2 has been activated by Ga-RhH. The energy barrier of this process is low to 14.5 kcal/mol, demonstrating that the activation of the H2SiMe2 process catalyzed by Ga-RhH is easy to occur under the experimental conditions. 3.2.2 Insertion of phenylacetonitrile, reductive elimination, and isomerization Subsequently, reactant 3 goes towards INT3 to form COM3. At this time, the bond lengths of the C and N atoms in 3 with Rh atom are 2.247 Å and 2.408 Å, respectively. The bond length of C atom of 3 with the H atom of Ga-RhH is 2.526 Å, while the bond length of the N and Si atoms is 3.208 Å. Furthermore, the bond length of the CN triple in 3 is slightly extended from 1.174 Å to 1.208 Å, which makes it easier for 3 to selectively insert into the Rh-H bond or Rh-Si bond. For the insertion of 3 into the Rh-H bond, when the Rh-H bond increases to 1.702 Å and the CH bond shortens to 1.438 Å, TS4a is obtained. Moreover, the CN bond length increases to 1.231 Å. As the reaction proceeds, the CH bond decreases to 1.222 Å, and INT4a forms. Then, with the gradual shortening of the N-Si bond length and the increase of the Rh-N bond and Rh-Si bond lengths, TS5a is reached when the N-Si bond length is shortened to 2.294 Å. This is followed by the formation of the intermediate INT5, which releases a large amount of heat. The energy barriers for the insertion of 3 into the Rh-H bond and the reductive elimination process are 20.0 kcal/mol and 3.2 kcal/mol, respectively. For the insertion of 3 into the Rh-Si bond, by reducing the N-Si bond length, INT4b is formed via TS4b, in which the bond length of the N-Si bond is 2.027 Å and the Rh-Si bond is shortened to 2.806 Å. The energy barrier of this process is 22.9 kcal/mol, which is 2.9 kcal/mol higher than the insertion of the Rh-H bond. Subsequently, INT5 is formed through TS5b, which has an energy barrier of 7.2 kcal/mol. Based on the traditional transition state theory, the corresponding reaction rate constants for the insertion of 3 process are calculated to be 1.36 × 10–2, and 1.02 × 10–4 s-1 M-1, respectively. It further implies that the insertion of the Rh-H bond is a superior reaction pathway, not the insertion of the Rh-Si bond. Finally, Z-A leaves away from INT5 and regenerates the Ga-RhH complex. Then Z-A undergoes a dihedral angle rotation to afford more thermodynamically stable product E-A via TS6. During this isomerization process, the dihedral angle HC-N-Si rotates from 178.5° in Z-A to 140.3° The energy barrier required to finish this process is only 3.3 kcal/mol, which is consistent with the main production of E-A observed in the experiment. Overall, the hydrosilylation of 3 catalyzed by Ga-RhH involves four processes, in which the insertion of the Rh-H bond is more favourable than that of the Rh-Si bond, and tends to produce more thermodynamically stable E-A. 3.3 Chemoselctivity between E-A and B The experimental results of Iwasawa et al. demonstrate that the formation of E-A as an initial hydrosilylation product, followed by a second hydrosilylation on E-A, gives rise to N,N-disilylamine B [5]. The PES of the hydrosilylation of E-A to form B is given in Fig. 6 with the structures labeled with the main parameters. Firstly, E-A gradually reacts with INT3 to form COM4. In COM4, the bond lengths of the Rh-C bond, Rh-N bond and the CH bond are 2.361 Å, 2.430 Å, and 2.565 Å, respectively. As the Rh-H bond length increases steadily, the CH bond gradually shortens until the Rh-H bond length is 1.649 Å and the CH bond length is 1.485 Å and then TS7 is achieved. At this time the Rh-C and Rh-N bond lengths are 2.373 Å and 2.319 Å respectively, demonstrating the formation of a η 2-coordination structure. The final product B is then generated via TS8 as the N-Si bond gradually becomes shorter. The energy barriers of these two processes are 23.0 kcal/mol, and 17.6 kcal/mol, respectively. The energy barrier for the insertion of E-A is 3.0 kcal/mol higher than that for the insertion of 3 into the Rh-H bond. This is reflected in the reaction rate constants, which are slower, at 8.59 × 10–5 s-1 M-1. Topographic steric maps are considered to be fingerprints of transition metal complexes [59,60]. The steric maps for TS4a and TS7 are calculated in Fig. 6. The percent buried volume (%VBur) highlights a difference in steric bulkiness between these two transition states, showing that the%VBur of TS7 is 80.9, which is significantly larger than that of TS4a (68.5). Both the reaction rate constants and topographic steric maps show the difficulty encountered during the second hydrosilylation of E-A to form B. These findings are in consistent with the experimental observations [5]. In order to ensure the reliability and accuracy of the calculation of simplification of PPh2 ligand to PMe2, the geometries of the 2-Al, 2-Ga, and 2-In with PMe2 ligands are optimized. The calculated bond lengths of the [E-Rh] bond in Rh-Al, Rh-Ga and Rh-In complexes are 2.415 Å, 2.389 Å and 2.509 Å, respectively for E=Al, Ga, and In. Comparing to the XRD crystal data of Iwasawa et al., which are 2.423 Å, 2.402 Å, and 2.502 Å for the Rh-Al, Rh-Ga, and Rh-In bonds, respectively, the differences are within 0.1 Å. Then the processes of the title reaction catalyzed by Ga-RhPPh2 catalyst were calculated and the PES of the hydrosilylation reaction is shown in Fig. S6. It clearly shows that when using Ga-RhPPh2 as the catalyst, the rate-determining step is also the activation of H2SiMe2 process, with an energy barrier of 22.1 kcal/mol, which is close to that catalyzed by Ga-RhPMe2 (23.4 kcal/mol). In the subsequent processes of the selective insertion of phenylacetonitrile, the energy barrier of the insertion into the Rh-H bond is 16.2 kcal/mol, and that of the insertion into the Rh-Si bond is 19.1 kcal/mol, this energy barrier difference (ΔGTS4b - ΔGTS4a = 2.9 kcal/mol) is the same as that using Ga-RhPMe2 as the catalyst, maintaining the reaction a high selectivity. Therefore, the using of PMe2 model is reasonable. 3.4 Evaluation of the monometallic RhCl(PPh3)3 catalysis pathway The standard monometallic RhCl(PPh3)3 catalyst was also used in Iwasawa's experiment and afforded products with low yield [5]. The monometallic RhCl(PPh3)3 catalyst was evaluated in comparison to the heterobimetallic catalysts, the PES of the hydrosilylation catalyzed by RhCl(PPh3)3 is investigated and displayed in Fig. S7, and the corresponding optimized structures are shown in Fig. S8. The reaction mechanism of the hydrosilylation of 3 catalyzed by RhCl(PPh3)3 is similar to that of 2-Ga. This reaction is initiated by the dissociation of the PPh3 ligand from the RhCl(PPh3)3 catalyst to form RhCl(PPh3)2 (denoted as RhCl), providing a vacancy for the reaction [61]. As shown in Figs. S7 and S8, the hydrosilylation of 3 catalyzed by RhCl contains four processes: activation of H2SiMe2; coordination of phenylacetonitrile; insertion of phenylacetonitrile; and reductive elimination. It can be seen that the energy barrier for the activation of H2SiMe2 process is extremely low, at about 6.8 kcal/mol. Whereas the energy barrier for the coordination of 3 is as high as 28.5 kcal/mol, which is 5.1 kcal/mol higher than that of the rate-determining step catalyzed by Ga-RhH. Furthermore, the energy barriers for the insertion of 3 into the Rh-H bond and reductive elimination are 25.1 and 1.4 kcal/mol, respectively. Finally, Z -A is produced and the monometallic RhCl is regenerated again. The high energy barrier catalyzed by RhCl demonstrates the difficulty of the reaction occurring under the experimental conditions of 70 °C [5]. Obviously, the presence of the metal-metal bond in the bimetallic catalyst 2-Ga facilitates the reaction to proceed in the Rh atom. 3.5 QTAIM analysis of the structures along the reaction pathway In order to gain insight into the role of the Cl atom in the reaction pathways, a comparative QTAIM analysis is performed for key points along the IRC reaction pathway. The corresponding molecular graphs are displayed in Figs. 7 and S9, with the electron density ρ(r) for BCP listed in Table S2. Take 2-Ga as an example, it is evident that the presence of a BCP (the green dot) indicates the existence of a Rh-Cl2 bond in Ga-COM1. As the reaction proceeds, both the Rh-Cl2 and Ga-Cl2 bonds exhibit the BCP at S=−6.22, resulting in the formation of a three-membered ring structure with an RCP (the red dot) between one bridging Rh-Cl2-Ga moiety, which is similar to the bridging Al-H-Ir moiety in Al-Ir complex [62]. At S = 0.00, the transition state is reached. The three-membered ring structure and the BCP of the Rh-Cl2 bond all disappear, and only one BCP exists on the Ga-Cl2 bond, indicating that the Rh-Cl2 bond has been broken and the Ga-Cl2 bond has been formed. The topological structure changes indicate that in the reaction catalyzed by 2-Ga, the Cl2 atom transfers from the Rh atom to the Ga atom. After Ga-TS1, the Cl3 atom on the Ga atom approaches the Rh atom, a three-membered ring structure of Rh-Cl3-Ga is generated at S = 49.10. This structure persists until the formation of Ga-INT1, suggesting the formation of the Rh-Cl3 bond. The BCPs and RCPs demonstrate a high degree of agreement with the structural changes along the reaction pathway. These findings confirm that the Cl atom can move between the Rh-Ga bond. A similar change occurring is also observed along the reaction pathway catalyzed by 2-Al and 2-In, which is shown in Fig. S9. The QTAIM analysis shows the transformation of the Cl atom between E and Rh atoms, thereby providing a more profound theoretical foundation for understanding the mechanisms of structural changes in catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusions The electronic structure of the heterobimetallic complexes [E-Rh] (E=Al, Ga, In) and the detailed mechanisms of phenylacetonitrile hydrosilylation catalyzed by E-Rh (E=Al, Ga, In) complexes were investigated by DFT calculations, as well as the monometallic RhCl(PPh3)3 catalyst was evaluated. In the hydrosilylation reaction catalyzed by 2-Al, 2-Ga, and 2-In, the whole reaction mechanism involves five processes: the formation of rhodium hydride complex; activation of H2SiMe2; insertion of phenylacetonitrile; reductive elimination; and isomerization. Among the formation of rhodium hydride catalyst process, there are two steps via the activation of H2SiMe2 and Cl-Si coupling. The energy barrier of the activation of H2SiMe2 is the rate-determining step for the entire reaction, and the reaction activity of 2-Al, 2-Ga, and 2-In decreases in the order of Al, Ga, and In, which is consistent with the dipole moment of E-Th bond and the atomic contribution of Rh in E-Rh (E=Al, Ga, In). The very low energy barrier and the instability of Al-RhH catalyst makes the low yield of 2-Al, Only 2-Ga exhibits superior catalytic activity. The DI analysis demonstrates that the catalytic activity is controlled by the distortion energy. In the hydrosilylation of phenylacetonitrile catalyzed by Ga-RhH, the insertion of the Rh-H bond is more favourable than that of the Rh-Si bond. E-A is the main product with a lower%VBur (68.5) compared to the formation of B. Our calculation results are in agreement with and provide detailed explanations for the experimental observations. It is anticipated that the results will be beneficial for the more efficient design of heterobimetallic catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Transition metals catalyzed hydrosilylation reaction is of significant values in organic synthesis. Herein the detailed mechanisms of the phenylacetonitrile hydrosilylation catalyzed by bimetallic [E-Rh] (E=Al, Ga, In) catalysts, as well as the RhCl(PPh3)3 monometallic catalyst, were investigated by DFT calculations. The electronic structure analysis indicates that the different atomic contributions of the Rh atom in E-Rh bond result in the polarity variations of the metal-metal bonds and different catalytic activities. The whole catalyzed cycle involves five processes: the formation of rhodium hydride complex, activation of H2SiMe2, insertion of phenylacetonitrile, reductive elimination, and isomerization. The reaction activities of [E-Rh] (E=Al, Ga, In) decrease successively, which is in agreement with the atomic contributions of Rh in three catalysts. DI analysis provides the evidence that the catalytic activity is controlled by the distortion energy of rate-determining state. QTAIM analysis shows the transformation of the Cl atom between two metal atoms, providing a clear description for structural changes in catalytic cycle.
